thread.title: Football coaches address N.J. QB tragedy: 'It's really hard to comprehend'
thread.title_full: Football coaches address N.J. QB tragedy: 'It's really hard to comprehend'

title: Football coaches address N.J. QB tragedy: 'It's really hard to comprehend'
text:
By Greg Joyce | For lehighvalleylive.com on September 30, 2015 6:58 PM View/Post Comments 
Though they may not have direct ties to Warren Hills , local football teams have still been struck by the sudden loss of Blue Streaks quarterback Evan Murray. 
While most teams were playing around the Lehigh Valley last Friday night, Murray was on the field against Summit before he left the game, collapsed on the sideline and later died from what was found to be a lacerated spleen . 
“It’s so tragic I don’t think the kids might realize it yet themselves, at their age, as to what really happened and how that’s going to shake up that school and that family,” Easton coach Steve Shiffert said. 
Shiffert said he addressed the situation with his team with some help from the Red Rovers’ team trainer. 
“We had our trainer talk to our kids and explain, to the best of his knowledge, what happened and what they have to look for for warning signs,” Shiffert said. “It’s something the kids have to be aware of. 
“It’s very unfortunate and obviously our sympathies go out to that team and that family.” 
RELATED : Warren Hills mourns at wake for QB Evan Murray 
Freedom coach Jason Roeder said he talked with his team about it briefly earlier this week. 
“It’s just an unbelievable tragedy,” Roeder said. “Your heart goes out to all the people involved, especially the Murray family and their school community. … It’s really hard to comprehend.” 
Lehigh football coach Andy Coen had a different situation, with his team playing the day after Murray’s death. He decided not to address it with his team before its game at Princeton Saturday night, but still hasn’t stopped thinking about it. 
“That’s awful,” Coen said. “I felt so bad. I didn’t even know how to handle that.” 
Warren Hills comes to Lehigh’s 7-on-7 “Shoot-Out” camp every summer, run by defensive backs coach Craig Sutyak – who had also recruited that area in New Jersey for a long time. 
“Their coach (Larry Dubiel) is a great guy,” Coen said. “That made me sick to my stomach. … It’s tragic.”
